entry.title: A stranger through a city
entry.content:
The window banged into my head and woke me up from my drifting sleep.  The bus was slowing down for its next stop but the window sized potholes in the street were too much for the bus's old suspension system to smooth out. 

"53rd and Park," the bus operator called out over the tinny speaker system.  An elderly woman covered in long trench coat slowly made her way to the front, thanked the driver and exited the bus.  Once safely cleared, 3 noisy teenagers climbed aboard.

"Yo, I'm telling you, that's what happened.  Why won't you believe me man?"  a lean boy with long black hair pleaded with his two friends.  They both began to laugh as they took their seats on the bus.

"You always tell the tallest tales!  You're like a professional storyteller.  You should go into showbiz.  I'm sure you'll make millions" the taller boy retorted. 

"Dude, you are a bigger lier than Trump, heck, forget that, a bigger lier than Hillary!" a chubbier boy added.  The long black haired boy shaked his head with disbelief. 

"It's up to you if you don't believe me!  Your loss!" he exclaimed.

The bus started moving again and entered on to the highway.  The next stop wouldn't happen for at least 15 minutes depeneding on highway traffic conditions.  I looked out over the ramp and saw an endless stream of cars packed tightly.  I sighed.  It would be at least an hour before I would be able to make it home.  This would be the 3rd time this month that I had missed the early bus and settled for the 6 o clock.  I bundled up my hoodie and wedged it under my head between the window and the headrest.  It was quite comfortable and warm.  I could even fall asleep if the seats on the bus weren't so upright. 

As the bus begain its stop-and-go jounry through the 4 lane gridlock, I drifted asleep again to the sound of the bus's soft engine.  My mind slipped back to my meeting from 5 weeks ago which had led me to be where I was now.
entry.summary: The window banged into my head and woke me up from my drifting sleep.  The bus was slowing down for its next stop but the window sized potholes in the street were too much for the bus's old suspension system to smooth out.  "53rd and Park," the bus operator called out over the tinny speaker system.  An elderly woman covered in long trench coat slowly made her way to the front, thanked the driver and exited the bus.  Once safely cleared, 3 noisy teenagers climbed aboard. "Yo, I'm telling you, that's what happened.  Why won't you believe me man?"  a lean boy with long black hair pleaded with his two friends.  They both began to laugh as they took their seats on the bus. "You always tell the tallest tales!  You're like a professional storyteller.  You should go into showbiz.  I'm sure you'll make millions" the taller boy retorted.  "Dude, you are a bigger lier than Trump, heck, forget that, a bigger lier than Hillary!" a chubbier boy added.  The long black haired boy shaked his head with disbelief.  "It's up to you if you don't believe me!  Your loss!" he exclaimed. The bus started moving again and entered on to the highway.  The next stop wouldn't happen for at least 15 minutes depeneding on highway traffic conditions.  I looked out over the ramp and saw an endless stream of cars packed tightly.  I sighed.  It would be at least an hour before I would be able to make it home.  This would be the 3rd time this month that I had missed the early bus and settled for the 6 o clock.  I bundled up my hoodie and wedged it under my head between the window and the headrest.  It was quite comfortable and warm.  I could even fall asleep if the seats on the bus weren't so upright.  As the bus begain its stop-and-go jounry through the 4 lane gridlock, I drifted asleep again to the sound of the bus's soft engine.  My mind slipped back to my meeting from 5 weeks ago which had led me to be where I was now.

entry.title: When you put your fingers on the keyboardâ€¦

link.title: When you put your fingers on the keyboard...

entry.content:
I can do it.  I can write!  I have so many great ideas to share and people will want to read what I write.  That is what I told myself when I started to write for a blog.  But when the time came to actually put ink on paper, or in this case type text between <p>s, the task was much more daunting, and doubt creeps in.  Who would want to read what I write on this corner of the internet.  There is a whole internet out there for people to read!  Reddit, wikipedia, facebook, twitter.  Who has time for traditional blog reading nowadays anyway.  It, espcially, will not be people listening to podcasts or those endlessly watching cat videos on loop on youtube(I think I already use that expression too much).  But, alas, I must remind myself- the blog created here is not particularly meant to read to be consumed by a large unknown, uncaring, and usually quite critical, crowd.  Rather, it is nothing more than an exercise in my creative ability in the hopes that it will leave me feeling fulfilled. 

But that cannot be the only goal that is achieved.  If my ideas were to resonate with some reader, perhaps then they may nod their heads in agreement and perhaps lead to a certain sort of epipheny for them.  In any case, this blog can hopefully function as a public journal to semi stream-of-consciousness sort of blabbering.  There isn't even a spell check that I am using right now!
entry.summary: I can do it.  I can write!  I have so many great ideas to share and people will want to read what I write.  That is what I told myself when I started to write for a blog.  But when the time came to actually put ink on paper, or in this case type text between <p>s, the task was much more daunting, and doubt creeps in.  Who would want to read what I write on this corner of the internet.  There is a whole internet out there for people to read!  Reddit, wikipedia, facebook, twitter.  Who has time for traditional blog reading nowadays anyway.  It, espcially, will not be people listening to podcasts or those endlessly watching cat videos on loop on youtube(I think I already use that expression too much).  But, alas, I must remind myself- the blog created here is not particularly meant to read to be consumed by a large unknown, uncaring, and usually quite critical, crowd.  Rather, it is nothing more than an exercise in my creative ability in the hopes that it will leave me feeling fulfilled.  But that cannot be the only goal that is achieved.  If my ideas were to resonate with some reader, perhaps then they may nod their heads in agreement and perhaps lead to a certain sort of epipheny for them.  In any case, this blog can hopefully function as a public journal to semi stream-of-consciousness sort of blabbering.  There isn't even a spell check that I am using right now!

entry.title: How much ram do you need in 2018

link.title: How much ram do you need in 2018

entry.content:
How much ram do you really need? 8gb? 16gb? 64gb? What about a monstrous 128gb?

Short answer

As much as you can afford, because more is always better, and the additional power draw is negligable in this case.

Long Answer

If you're shopping for a laptop, you are likely to see ads for laptops that have usually 8gb or 16b configurations.  If price is no object, then it usually makes sense to buy a machine with as much ram as possible to 'future-proof' it as much as possible.  However, quite often, the extra ram may not be useful if you don't actually use it for anything.  For web browsing and watching cat videos on youtube 8gb, or even 4gb on a windows machine will be more than sufficient.  Most smartphones that are released in 2018 actually tend to have less than 4gb of ram as well.  One of the differences between phones and desktops is that phones are more aggressive at suspending, or terminating unused applications in the foreground.  Usually the phones that tend to have more ram have more advanced capabilities to run applications in true multitasking containers.

Personally, I buy the largest sticks of ram possible that are accepted by my motherboard.  I currently have 2x16gb of ram in my desktop.  However, I have never come close to utilizing even half of it.   But of course, I have a habit of closing unused applications.  At the time of writing, I am running a virtual box instance, and a chrome browser on a Windows 10 host machine.  Task manager reports that chrome is using 2.3gb of ram, while the virtual box manager is using ~0.1gb.  It seems that the usage by  ubuntu virtual machine does not appear in windows Task Manager.  This should be something that could need to be fixed or it might be a 'feature' of virtualbox.
entry.summary: How much ram do you really need? 8gb? 16gb? 64gb? What about a monstrous 128gb? Short answer As much as you can afford, because more is always better, and the additional power draw is negligable in this case. Long Answer If you're shopping for a laptop, you are likely to see ads for laptops that have usually 8gb or 16b configurations.  If price is no object, then it usually makes sense to buy a machine with as much ram as possible to 'future-proof' it as much as possible.  However, quite often, the extra ram may not be useful if you don't actually use it for anything.  For web browsing and watching cat videos on youtube 8gb, or even 4gb on a windows machine will be more than sufficient.  Most smartphones that are released in 2018 actually tend to have less than 4gb of ram as well.  One of the differences between phones and desktops is that phones are more aggressive at suspending, or terminating unused applications in the foreground.  Usually the phones that tend to have more ram have more advanced capabilities to run applications in true multitasking containers. Personally, I buy the largest sticks of ram possible that are accepted by my motherboard.  I currently have 2x16gb of ram in my desktop.  However, I have never come close to utilizing even half of it.   But of course, I have a habit of closing unused applications.  At the time of writing, I am running a virtual box instance, and a chrome browser on a Windows 10 host machine.  Task manager reports that chrome is using 2.3gb of ram, while the virtual box manager is using ~0.1gb.  It seems that the usage by  ubuntu virtual machine does not appear in windows Task Manager.  This should be something that could need to be fixed or it might be a 'feature' of virtualbox.

entry.title: Jekyll tips
entry.content:
Some tips- in no particular order

Tip #1

It's perfectly valid to mix .markdown files and .html files in your _posts folder.
entry.summary: Some tips- in no particular order Tip #1 It's perfectly valid to mix .markdown files and .html files in your _posts folder.

entry.title: Gotchyas presented by jekyll
entry.content:
Gotchya #1

 Out of the box, the rendering engine (is it liquid?) will not render pages that are date stamped at a future time.  Spent 20 minutes trying to figure out why my page wasnt generating.  =(

Gotchya #2

The date prepended in the post file name (yyyy-mm-dd-you-post-name) does not matter at all.  In fact, the title also does not matter.  The values in the "front matter" portion of the posts is what is used to determine if a post will be generated for the site.
entry.summary: Gotchya #1  Out of the box, the rendering engine (is it liquid?) will not render pages that are date stamped at a future time.  Spent 20 minutes trying to figure out why my page wasnt generating.  =( Gotchya #2 The date prepended in the post file name (yyyy-mm-dd-you-post-name) does not matter at all.  In fact, the title also does not matter.  The values in the "front matter" portion of the posts is what is used to determine if a post will be generated for the site.

entry.title: How will I write content?
entry.content: One of the challenges of getting started with jekyll is figuring out how to write content for your site.  After doing a very quick search of what's actually available and what other jekyllers are using, I have decided to move forward with using a visual editor like wordtohtml.net. Familiarity with HTML leaves me the option to use other tools or templates to write content more simply.  Also, if I find that I don't actually like using this pattern for writing content, the promise from jekyll is that it is easy to change.  I have my fingers crossed.
